text:
Stronger HK dollar diverting Mainland Chinese tourists Published on : Thursday, October 1, 2015
The Hong Kong dollar is getting stronger and has dealt another blow to the struggling tourism sector, with a fall in arrivals from Southeast Asia and Japan adding to a growing sense of gloom.
In the past one year some Asian currencies have slumped against the Hong Kong dollar, which is pegged to the greenback, to their lowest levels since the Asian financial crisis in 1998, deterring regional travellers.
Visitors from Southeast Asia fell by 5.6 per cent, year on year, in August – following a 5.1 per cent decline in July – with Indonesian tourists down 35.6 per cent, South Koreans dropping by 22.6 per cent and Japanese down 8.4 per cent.
Economists say the US dollar is likely to remain strong on the back of an expected interest rate rise, which means the city’s tourism and retail sectors could be heading for their worst time since the onset of the global financial crisis in 2008, and severe acute respiratory syndrome in 2003.
To add insult to injury, regional countries are now favoured destinations of mainlanders who once visited Hong Kong.
The Malaysian ringgit has tumbled about 25 per cent, Indonesia’s rupiah is down about 22 per cent, and there has been a 10 to 14 per cent decline in the Japanese yen, Thai baht, South Korean won and Singaporean dollar.
The yuan, which Beijing devalued in September to boost exports, fell 2.4 per cent between August and September.
“This is the biggest slide I have ever seen,” tourism sector legislator Yiu Si-wing said. “What hurts the tourism and retail sectors is that mainlanders are diverting to these other countries where their money could go a way longer.”
Mainland Chinese account for about 80 per cent of Hong Kong’s tourist arrivals, with the rest made up largely of Southeast Asian visitors. Any decline in visitor numbers will have a ripple effect on retail sales in Hong Kong, which have shrunk for the fifth straight month since March.
A recent Credit Suisse report showed Japan and Thailand have become the top draws for mainland tourists, with numbers to Japan up 133 per cent and Thailand 115 per cent year on year in August. Their numbers to Hong Kong in September dropped 0.2 per cent and 7.1 per cent in August.
“The movement in foreign exchange means our products are about three per cent more expensive to mainlanders,” said Lau Hak-bun, sales director of jewellery retailer Chow Sang Sang.
“The price difference is huge as consumer goods are getting at least 10 per cent cheaper in Europe and Southeast Asia.”
A recent report from financial services firm UBS said the strong Hong Kong dollar was also hurting the city’s competitiveness in exports. It expected the tourism industry to suffer worse than during the global financial crisis.
